results.title: How to make a movie
results.brief_description: Although short and largely created to practise the Straford Brothers’ unique approach to editing and transitions, this already shows their ambitions for scene and story. Here, a frustrated filmmaker tries to make a ‘classic.’
results.description: Although short and largely created to practise the Straford Brothers’ unique approach to editing and transitions, this already shows their ambitions for scene and story. Here, a frustrated filmmaker tries to make a ‘classic.’

results.title: Little Claude - a'hunting he will go
results.brief_description: The Straford Brothers’ first attempt at a hand drawn animation. Frank recalls that it was done by drawing on a single cell, filming it, then rubbing it out and drawing the next frame on top, “a pretty laborious way to make an animation.”

results.title: ARTV
results.brief_description:
The Australian Centre for the Moving Image and SBS Independent will commission 16 artists to produce works for ARTV, an exhibition program which will be broadcast on SBS and shown on screens throughout ACMI concurrently, commencing on 8 June 2004.

ARTV is part of 2004, a survey exhibition of contemporary Australian visual culture presented by the Australian Centre for the Moving Image and the National Gallery of Victoria.

results.title: K-Rad Man
results.brief_description: A Mad Scientist creates the ultimate computer virus and locates a suitable test subject: K-Rad Man - to whom he can expose the computer virus and gauge its results.

results.title: Drat
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Robert Stephenson, Ann Shenfield, Sarah Watt and Elizabeth O'Neill
results.brief_description: A bunch of lab rats one night decide to break out and escape from their cages in the laboratory. One brain damaged rat, as a result of receiving shock-treatment, initially resists the call. This claymation reveals in its close yet another fiendish experiment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Robert Stephenson, Ann Shenfield, Sarah Watt and Elizabeth O’Neill

results.title: Paddington in the hot seat. Paddington's puzzle. Paddington takes a cut.
results.creator_credit: Barry Leith, Ivor Wood, Graham Clutterbuck, FilmFair Communications and Paddington
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
1. “Paddington in the hot seat”. Paddington has an audience ticket for the Quiz Show “Sage of Britain”. He gets lost in the studio complex and finds himself “on camera” where he is interviewed by Lionel Parr. He disputes the scoring and provides his opinion on proposed changes to British Television. The viewers jam the switchboard and Paddington is announced “Sage of Britain”. - 2. “Paddington’s puzzle”. Paddington makes a jigsaw puzzle as a present for Mr Gruber from a “priceless” old painting discarded by Mr Curry, some plywood and glue. - 3. “Paddington takes a cut”. Paddington reads “Clippings from my Hedgerow” and dreams he is pruning Mr Currys’ shrub into a peacock shape. Disaster strikes when he snips it leg off! However, awakes before discovery by Mr Curry!
results.title_for_label: Paddington in the hot seat. Paddington’s puzzle. Paddington takes a cut.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Leith, Ivor Wood, Graham Clutterbuck, FilmFair Communications and Paddington

He gets lost in the studio complex and finds himself “on camera” where he is interviewed by Lionel Parr. He disputes the scoring and provides his opinion on proposed changes to British Television. results.title: Hyper >> [games magazine] Issue 100, February 2002
results.brief_description:
Hyper was a multi-platform Australian video game magazine. It was Australia’s longest running gaming magazine, published from 1993 to 2019.

In addition to coverage of current major video game systems and game releases, Hyper also covered anime, DVD movies, arcade and classic games, and featured interviews with industry professionals and articles on game-related content such as game classifications, computer hardware and video game music. Hyper also had a sister magazine, the PC gaming oriented PC PowerPlay. (citation from Wikipedia).

A digital version of the magazine can be found here: https://archive.org/details/hyper-100
